sub_title: Senior Officer Impact & Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) at Invest International
summary:
Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) specialist on international infrastructure projects with competencies in project management (IPMA-C / APM PQ). Experience with Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) and international standards and best practices such as the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises, UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, IFC Performance Standards, and World Bank Safeguards / Environmental Social Framework (ESF). Specialised in the development and review of Environmental and Social Impact Assessments (ESIA) and Management Plans (ESMP).

Sectors: Coastal Protection, Public Health, Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM), Solid Waste, and Water and Sanitation.

International experience:
Burkina Faso, DR Congo, Egypt, Ghana,  Indonesia, Sao Tomé en Principe, South Africa, South Sudan, Mozambique, Tanzania, The Netherlands.

projects.title: Professionalisation of the horticulture sector, in particular the multiplication of seed potatoes
projects.description:
Environmental & Social Expert

The objective of the requested study is to assess the possibilities to revitalise and rehabilitate the Centre de Promotion de l’Horticulture (CPH) in Dalaba in order to improve the  horticultural production in Guinea, reinforce the capacity and knowledge of the CPH regarding production and promotion of horticultural products grown in the region specifically potatoes, and of improving food security in general. 
The assignment is set-up in two phases A and B respectively, with a go/no-go decision foreseen in between:
Phase A consists of studies to analyse the horticultural sector, to determine what is necessary to rehabilitate and revitalise the CPH in terms of functionality and capacity, and to assess the financial, economic, institutional and environmental feasibility of the project.  This stage includes a preliminary Technical Design and Cost Assessment as well as an Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA).

Phase B consists of the preparation of a tender dossier for selecting a contractor, which will rehabilitate and build the infrastructure of the CPH, deliver the required equipment and supply the required technical assistance. This will include drafting the overall specifications and design criteria  to enable the contractor to prepare the Detailed Design and cost estimates. As well as specifications on the Technical Assistance to be supplied. The output of phase B will be a complete tender package for a design and build project ready to be put in the market.

contributors.headline: Senior Officer Impact & Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) at Invest International

projects.title: Coastal protection for the District of Agua Grande
projects.description:
Environmental & Social Expert

In order to mitigate the adverse impact of climate change, the Government of São Tomé and Principe and Develop2Build are developing coastal protection infrastructure in the district of Agua Grande. The ultimate objective of these proposed works is to reduce the vulnerability of the country's capital, São Tomé, to the risks linked to extreme marine phenomena of the climate change by strengthening resilience and promoting the reconstruction of the Ana Chaves bay for tourist exploitation and development of the country. The Ministry of Public Works, Infrastructure, Natural Resources and Environment (MOPIRNA) is the Executing Agency for this project. Develop2Build and MIRNA are working together with the World Bank and the European Investment Bank for the implementation of this project.

projects.title: Develop a Water Supply Master Plan and Detailed Design for Beira and Dondo
projects.description:
Environmental & Social Expert

The Fundo de Investimento e Património do Abastecimento de Água (FIPAG), on behalf of the Republic of Mozambique, has received a Grant from the Government of the Netherlands through the Netherlands Enterprise Agency (RVO.nl) under the umbrella of The Develop 2 Build (D2B) Fund. The fund will be applied for a contract to develop a Water Supply Master Plan and Detailed Design for Beira and Dondo.

contributors.headline: Senior Officer Impact & Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) at Invest International

projects.title: Water Supply Upper East Region Ghana
projects.description:
Environmental & Social Expert

The Upper East Region is located in the North Eastern part of Ghana. Bordering Burkina Faso and Togo. The major cities are Bolgatanga, Bongo and Navrongo. Serious restraints in the drinking water supply are identified throughout the area. The existing water supply system has inadequate capacity to meet the demand. The high population growth in the larger cities increases the shortages. The area generally is quite arid which has also resulted in migration to the larger cities. At this moment there is a small drinking WTP located between Bolgatanga and Bongo, supplying both cities with insufficient capacity. After the foreseen system change this WTP will be dedicated to Bongo and its surroundings. The raw water source for this system the Vea irrigation reservoir is exploited to its limit which eliminates the possibility of extended use. To supply the cities of Bolgatanga Navrongo and their surroundings a new raw water source and a new WTP is foreseen. The above solution will close the demand gap after its completion. The number of people that will be supplied with potable water in 2030 is estimated to be 310,488. Of these people 230,488 currently do not have access to potable water. The remaining 80,000 will have access to a more reliable connection.

contributors.headline: Senior Officer Impact & Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) at Invest International

projects.title: Trachoma SAFE Programme
projects.description:
Country: Tanzania | Arusha, Dodoma & Lindi Region
Budget: € 350,000/=
Donor: Sightsavers/DfID/The Queen Elizabeth Diamond Jubilee Trust

The project activities are implemented in eight districts across the regions of Arusha, Dodoma and Lindi in Tanzania. Challenges related to the reduction of trachoma infection risks are manifold. There are many pastoralist communities with nomadic lifestyles that lack proper homes with access to safe water-, sanitation- and hygiene facilities. Animals are often in or close to dwelling areas. On the other hand, cities can be densely populated creating other hygiene issues with respect to fly control / environmental cleanliness e.g. due to bad sanitary facilities. General problems are high illiteracy rates and high poverty among the populations in all three regions.

Overall Objective:
The overall objective of the programme is to reduce the prevalence rates of trachoma in the six regions in Tanzania that have the highest burden of trachoma infection.

contributors.headline: Senior Officer Impact & Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) at Invest International

projects.title: WASH & Learn! in Tanzania
projects.description:
Country: Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda
Budget: € 1,890,000
Donor: Walking for Water 2016-2018 | Rotary District 1570 | Aqua for All

WASH & Learn is implemented in line with a results framework that tracks progress made against key outcome and output indicators.

Several key outcome and output indicators that Simavi tracks with its partners are:
1) Improved access to, and use of, WASH facilities for 19,380 pupils at school. This will result in structural improvement of:
- Health;
- School attendance and learning;
- Enrolment (especially for girls);
- Working conditions for teachers.

Improved sustainable access to, and use of, WASH facilities for 26,470 people from the communities surrounding the schools. This will result in a structural improvement of basic health and will empower communities to improve their own situation after the project’s completion.

Improved capacity of local NGOs in:
- Implementing WASH programmes in schools and the community by sharing knowledge regionally.
- Business skills: 1) assessing projects or interventions on financial sustainability; 2) assessing the quality and skills of local entrepreneurs
- Technical skills: 1) Choosing the appropriate WASH technology; 2) Working with local building contractors; 3) Monitoring and assessing the quality of work done by contractors.
- Improved capacity and involvement of local entrepreneurs in providing WASH services to schools, households and communities.

contributors.headline: Senior Officer Impact & Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) at Invest International
Program Management | Water, Sanitation & Hygiene | SDGs | organisation development & strengthening

projects.title: Trachoma SAFE Communities
projects.description:
Country: Tanzania | Manyara Region
Budget: € 300,000
Donor: Simavi

Main objective

To prevent the spread of trachoma by changing community behaviour towards good personal hygiene and environmental sanitation practices within the project areas. We will do this by implementing the WHO strategy on eradicating trachoma in an integrated WASH intervention.

Together with local partner CBHCC, Simavi implement the Trachoma SAFE Communities programme to prevent the further spread of trachoma by changing community behaviour towards good personal hygiene and environmental sanitation practices within the project areas. We will do this by implementing the WHO-implemented SAFE strategy on eradicating trachoma in an integrated WASH intervention.

The SAFE-strategy stands for Surgery, Antibiotic, Face Washing and Environmental Sanitation. Within our programme, Simavi will specifically focus on the Facial cleanness (F) and Environmental sanitation (E) components of the SAFE Strategy.

projects.title: Sustainable Rural Sanitation Services Program (SRSSP) – Project Management Consultancy Firm Services (PMCF), Egypt – The Ministry of Housing, Utilities, and Urban Communities (MHUUC)
projects.description: Assistant Project Manager / Water and Sanitation Expert. The objective of the Sustainable Rural Sanitation Services Program for Results (Program) is to enhance rural sanitation services as well as strengthen institutions and policies for increasing access in the Delta Governorates of Beheira, Dakahlia and Sharkeya in Egypt. The programme is financed by the World Bank through a Program for Results (PforR) totalling US$ 550 million and is to be completed by October 2020, as Phase I.

contributors.headline: Senior Officer Impact & Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) at Invest International

projects.title: MKAJI Programme
projects.description:
Location: Tanzania, Dodoma Region
Budget: €7,916,168
Donor: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC)

Water supply in the Dodoma region of Tanzania are either malfunctioning or non-existent. This poses a great health problem, especially at primary health care level, where the majority (almost 70%) of the population seeks healthcare services.

Overall objective:
Improve access to water and hygiene promotion in 100 selected public primary health care facilities in the Dodoma region’s 7 districts.

Approach:
After receiving a request from regional authorities in Tanzania, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC), Simavi, Witteveen+Bos and three Tanzanian partners (CBHCC, PATUTA and UFUNDIKO), implemented the MKAJI programme to upgrade water supply and sanitation systems in 100 primary health facilities in the Dodoma region. Maj kwa Afya ya Jamii (MKAJI) is Swahili for  ‘Water for Community Health’.

This intervention will considerably reduce the potential risk of outbreak of communicable diseases and infections during routine patient care and treatment, and improve maternal health care and service delivery.

The consortium made a costing of standard solutions (such as connections to existing networks; boreholes, water tanks, surface water) for all health facilities without water, including upgrading sanitation systems. It has been agreed that SDC will complement local investment and cover between 18-22 primary health facilities per year for the 7 districts. By the end of this phase, 100 health facilities will have been improved. Water management and hygiene promotion in and with communities will complement hardware investments. The FIETS principles will be implemented to ensure sustainable change.

contributors.headline: Senior Officer Impact & Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) at Invest International
Programme Manager Make Way at Liliane Foundation

projects.title: WASH Alliance International in Ghana
projects.description:
Country: Ghana | Northern Region
Budget: €550,000
Donor: Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs

WASH Alliance International is a multi-national consortium of over 100 partners worldwide. We work together with local NGOs, governments and businesses to make sure everybody on this planet has sustainable access to water and sanitation.

In Africa we run programmes in Ghana, Mali, Benin, Uganda, Ethiopia and Kenya. In Asia, we work in Nepal and Bangladesh. In these countries we set up local alliances that enable us to optimally make use of local knowledge and networks and tap into existing WASH structures.

In Ghana more than 80 percent of people have access to safe water, but only 13% of people have access to improved sanitation. Dependency on unsafe water sources is higher in rural areas. Due to drinking contaminated water, diarrheal disease is the third most commonly reported illness at health centers across the country and 25% of all deaths in children under the age of five are attributed to diarrhea. In addition to lack of sanitation infrastructure, some cultural beliefs and views encourage people in rural areas not to use latrines.

contributors.headline: Senior Officer Impact & Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) at Invest International

profile_positions.description:
Invest International is a Joint Venture of the Dutch State (51%) and Development Bank FMO (49%) in which my previous position for Development Funds Develop2Build, DRIVE and ORIO was merged.

As Senior Officer Impact & ESG (Environmental, Social and Governance) in the Risk and Compliance Department, I am responsible form I-ESG Risk Management by advising the Engagement Committee and Investment Committee about the quality of the IESG analyses and evaluation and 
suggested actions. After which I monitor the portfolio to ensure  the committed actions meet our requirements.

Invest International applies a range of internationally recognized standards of best practice to assess 
ESG risks and adverse impacts of its investments. The standards used depend on the context, the type 
of segment of the client and the type of investment or support needed. 
We apply three core standards for the purpose of assessing ESG risks:
• IFC Performance Standards on Environmental and Social Sustainability and the 
World Bank Environmental Health and Safety (EHS) Guidelines.
• OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises.
• UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights.
profile_positions.title: Senior Officer Impact & Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG)
